ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course covers a large portion of the basic statistics that I believe every single person should know. Those not involved in research will undoubtedly come across statistics throughout their lives, and those who will be using statistics, now have a great basic background in it in which they could follow up with additional courses.
Stat 501 is an intense introduction to non calculus-based statistics with emphasis on applications. The second part of the course goes deeper into general linear models and nonparametric statistics.

I would recommend STAT 501 as a first (or even second) course in statistics for a student researcher. It combines sound theoretical explanations with relevant practical examples. There is also an emphasis on experimental design.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Statistics is crucial in almost every discipline. I have already applied some of the knowledge that I gained from this course in my own research.
I took this course as an elective so I enjoyed the course for it's own value.

I had taken introductory statistics before and picked up some methods on the job, but STAT 501 helped me better understand familiar methods and added some new ones to my repertoire. I also appreciate the emphasis on experimental design; good design lays the groundwork for proper analysis.
